p: The fruits, leaves, and roots of Piper guineense have diverse medicinal uses for treating convulsion, rheumatism, and respiratory diseases in African traditional medicine [ 2]. The inhalation of P. guineense EO had significant sedative and anxiolytic effects, suggesting that the EO might induce a mild tranquilizing effect. The main compounds of P. guineense EO were linalool (41.8%) and 3,5-dimethoxytoluene (10.9%). These two main compounds were shown to play a major role in the sedative activity of P. guineense EO [ 2]. The EO of Piper guineense might exert its sedative effects partially via the GABAergic receptor system [ 2].
